argument word framed commonwealth peraduenture heauen visible onely would attentiuelie behold eies good intelligence end hauing seene beheld imitation assay meanes conforme themselues vnto representing therefore forme commonwealth framed deuised according patron conceiued vvithin high diuine spirit hee much pleased satisfied therewith work well appeareth beginning timee wherein hauing collected principal point politick discourse sheweth great singular affection vnto worke withall wishing find excellent os •• r learned poet giue true praise commendation worthily deserueth therein grauity sentence eloquence word varietie exquisite proposition impossible finde thing artificially wrought hauing purposed represent vnto v image perfect true iust commonwealth hee hath intituled vvorke name pollicie iustice principally inforcing himselfe shew iustice hee esteemed true rule politicke institution wherevnto humane action ought wholly referred heauens continuall moouing running compassing earthly mould stirreth vp quickeneth seed thing whatsoeuer inclosed cast superficiall part thereof remaining within earth nourished water brought forth sprung vp force aire fire make ripe quickened naturall influence celestial plannets specially sunne moone admirable strange vertues doe still disperse cast forth euerie place perpetuall continuall desire naturall production thereby time season fill replenish world new creature plant hearbes tree stone mettals continue kind vse man whō thing earth made created notwithstanding reasonable polliticke production cannot receiue reape anie fruit thereof without iustice law magistrate good reason rightly tearmed minister god ordained appointed gouernement conseruation mankind due reasonable proportion distribute deuide among good thing vvhich daily diuine prouidence god giuen sent vnto seeing iustice force efficary better necessary vvorke done procured vnto man meanes mooue stirre vp vnto vvithout vvhich neither may liue either solitarie companie vvhatsoeuer therefore doth plato deserue great praise among haue either stablished commonweales vvritten forme gouernement specially hee groundeth principle commonweale vpon belong taker many accuse lawe doe oratour persuadeth vniust decree thing vnreasonable hee vanquished force become seruant subiect force vanquish strong diuers opinion matter euen among wisest themselues cause doubting varietie vertue accompanied abilitie meanes able much constraine also vanquisher alwayes preheminence goodnesse sort strength seemeth without vertue question equitie therefore account equitie right wrought loue others hee mightie commaundeth amongst different iarring opinion one containeth nothing thing worth either validitie credite •• namely hee excelleth vertue ought call bondslaue seruant vnwor • hie serue otherwise would come passe seeme noble become bondslaues sonnes bondman chance taken captiue sold warre cause would haue tearmed bondslaues • barbarous people • yet neuerthelesse affirming seeke nothing bondslaue nature wee haue touched beginning necessarily wee must say altogither bondslaues •• • auouch nobilitie namely onely noble amongst wholly betweene bondman freeman saue onely regarde vertue vice thinke man begetteth man beast beast good men beget good child • •• • nature • ymeth often time shee misseth marke thus wee see reason ambiguitie naturally bondslaues • na • urally freeman • determined thing expedient iust one •• serue another commaund necessarie obey beare rule consequently exercise authoritie master euen lawe nature hath ordained kinde gouernment lastly vnlawfull forme gouernment vnprofitable thing profitable part also auaileable whole helpeth bodie helpeth soule seruant certaine part master liuing part entreateth kinde seruitude commeth lawe alloweth captiue warre serue taker body good vanquished belong vnto vanquisher kind bondage seemeth vniust reason equitie proceed force violence thing contrary vnto rather voluntarinesse good commoditie securitie repose submit themselues willingly power excellent vertue neuerthelesse law defended others auouching conquerour doth alwaies excell vertue thinke esteeming iust mightier raigne ouer weaker vniustly others suppose thinke men borne free reason constrained force become bondslaue vnto constrainer romane ciuill lawyer make diuision law say measure end rich solon affirme verse according opinion common people end gathering good vpon good notwithstanding sith possessing good instrument housekeeping gouernment doubt hath end well instrument appointed directed owne end plinie woondring much dispraising men couetousnesse vnsatiable desire heape richesse vpon richesse neuer findeth end meanes whereof man neuer enioy blessednesse felicity might counteruaile kingdome ptolomeus great charge aid pompey subdued iury entertained vpon owne wage cost eight thousand horseman time made feast whereat thousand men sitting table euery one cuppe gold vpon seruing euery messe hee changed cuppes gold golden cuppes newe fashion howbeit saieth hee richesse small portion comparison richesse pythius bithinia gaue darius king persia plaine tree gold vine gold wherof went great fame still kept great remembrance pythius liberall hospitality housekeeping receaued king xerxes sonne said darius time hee made expedition greece hostile manner ledde army amounting number seuen hundred thousand men pythius feasted one day banquet pythius fiue sonnes king made proclamation men able fit weare armour passe greece hee offered king pay army space fiue moneths prouide corne time name child recompence thereof onely demanded resp eldest sonne stay home goe warres end absence foure might gouerne father age although pythius thus rich yet plinie affirmeth hee bee compared cresus king lydia infinite number golde therefore want wisedome man set heart farre vpon couetousnesse end whereof nothing el possesse great reuenues haue beene diuerse bondman haue beene greater ability richesse famous king nowe amongst king haue great aboundance possession cannot one bee found thought hee hoorded v • ynough plinie affirmeth pallas emperour neroes slaue got much vnder hee set libertie hee owner three thousand sexterces cornelius tacitus affirmeth value amount seuen million fiue hundred thousand crownes pliny affirmeth pallas richer crassus though crassus landes inheritance value fiue million golde though hee called rich man time richest romanes next silla neuerthelesse time claudius emperour three villaines bondslaues namely pallas child intemperate temperate vniuersally like may bee considered obeyer nature gouernour whether bee one selfesame diuerse vertue participate one selfesame vertue wherfore one rule obey continually cannot differ according lesse obeying gouerning differ kind respect lesse side wonder vertue bee desired one except gouernour bee temperate iust h • w hee gouerne well subiect bee howe shall bee well obey verily intemperate fearefull hee doe nothing comely meete therefore appeareth necessary participate vertue difference neuerthelesse found thinges subiection nature straightway perceaued soule one part commandeth nature obeyeth vertue partes wee affirme differ vertue part indued reason vnreasonable part certaine like obserued thinges insomuch nature bee diuers sort ruler obeyers free man gouerneth bondman one way male female another way man childe another sort part soule howbeit difference bondman altogether depriued part belongeth deliberation wife hath howbeit weake childe hath also imperfect like bee deemed morrall vertues wee must suppose ought haue howbeit maner measure measure conuenient office exercise euery one therefore expedient gouernour haue perfect morrall vertue office simply absolutely command giue order execution affaire reason beareth sway commanding appointing sufficeth euery person haue portion needfull • owne exercise let v conclude therefore person afore mentioned haue morrall vertue modestie husband wife selfe fortitude iustice socrates helde opinion one hath fortitude apt gouerne serue likewise vertues plainely may appeare particular consideration speake vniuersally doe deceaue themselues affirme hauing soule well disposed well like thing vertue number vertues gorgias say farre better others thus define therefore behoofefull deeme course turnes one another end bee equall giue place one another former magistrate giue place vnto beare rule othersome obey enterchangeably like diuersitie difference betweene meanes diuerse ruler doe obtaine diuerse magistrateships hereby knowe w • e contrarie nature cittie bee vnited men set downe vphold greatest welfare citties dooth ouerthrowe euerie thing preserued goodnesse thereof also respect gentleman commoner poore rich craftsman marchants laborer soldiours sufficiently bewray varietie diuersitie bee necessary therein notwithstanding contrarie manner vnion naturall thinges made element familie thinges differing sundry respect ought cittie bee composed diuerse kind order men howbeit doubt maintained vnitie good agreement ouerthrowne dissention discord recompence mutuall preferment equally bestowed dooth preserue defend city society men directed maintained due communicating thinges order person therefore bee two kindes iustice one commutatiue distributiue iustice commutatiue executed arithmeticall proportion pertaineth distribution exercised geometricall proportion arithmeticall equalitie requisite contract dealing well voluntarie violent end communicating commodity may bee euerlasting geometricall equalitie ought bee obserued distributing reward punishment bestowing honor magistrateships giuing euery man place handling according quality desert thing haue treated large two place first booke platoes commonweale reward mutuall preferring necessarily ought bee obserued among free equall cannot command haue magistrateships together gouerne yeares order time perrillouser hurtfuller pestilence cannot creepe commonweale part grow stronger rest vnpossible societie vnitie continue amongst cittizens vprightnesse equally obserued therein mixed compounded body dooth decay element whereof compact doe exceed rest euery tune goeth tune string stretch voice rise conuenient end commonweale may remaine safety ought one part growe stronger rest behooueth possible haue part publicke authority power therfore dominion commonweales lord cittizens equall distributing honour magistrateships ought obserued sort may beare rule turnes accordingly turne shall fall three yeares one yeare others eight month venetian gentleman doe haue whole gouernement power commonweale reserued counsell magistrate himselfe hath authority importance neither perpetuall sauing duke continueth life saint markes proctor haue prefixed time continue roomes till death expedient selfesame men alwaies gouerne like citty bee alwaies shoemaker carpenter youth learn occupation trade exercise long might continually magistrate best course philosopher opinion isocrates affirmeth oration symachus continue yeare prefixed time part goe office begin haue skill publicke affaire haue gotten experience therein continue office liues greatest part monarchy doe though officer haue lesse vnderstanding wit yet continuall exercise long experience may become skilfull discreet former magistrate giue place vnto beginning men gaue ouer magistrateships vnto ought giue ouer others sith together cannot possesse one another turnes like diuersitie difference betweene priuate person become magistrate magistrate priuate person seeme bee diuerse differing writeth last chapter former booke many ciuill gouernments ruler obeyers alter turnes bee equall according course nature differ nothing although one commaundeth obeyeth seeke difference apparrell speech honour amasis answered concerning tubbe serued wash feete conuerted image worshipped tale written herodotus euterpe meanes diuerse ruler doe obtaine diuerse magistrateships giuing place one another turnes euery man turn falleth doth exercise magistrateship differing another rome one aedile another pretour another assemblie woman end one hee would haue thousand men armes fiue thousand wherefore whole speech socrates carry indeede shew brauerie superfluous ambitious vaineglorious full nouelty doubtfull question peraduenture hard matter goe well therein especially regard multitude whereof wee spake late great surely would want necessary land babylon ample large countrey furnish victual many idle men fiue thousand farre greater companie woman seruants let therefore deuise supposition braine bee impossible moreouer hee sayeth lawgiuer hee maketh lawes ought haue regard two thinges place men amisse adde regard neighbour adioyning place end citie may haue politicke kinde life necessarie bee prouided weapon armes profitable onely selfe also may serue another countrie put case life city approoued neither particular publicke yet notwithstanding cittizens ought bee fearefull enemy onely •• ade border also retired besides regard ought bee possession whether quantitie might bee better say plainely manifestly defined set downe hee affirmeth ought bee much good cittie might suffice euery one l •• e temperately hee would say liue well generall speech man may liue temperately yet notwithstanding miserably wherefore better say temperately liberally together seperately taken luxurious life dooth follow one laborious considering vertuous habites doe onely consist vse good wee accustomed say man dooth vse good gently valiantly moderately liberally necessary vse consist impertinent absurd hee bringeth equalitie good possession determine nothing concerning multitude cittizens leaue large measure procreation child would necessarily come passe howe many soeuer borne yet would bee sufficient equalitie reason barrennesse wee see happen present citties neuerthelesse could bee exactly obserued reason nowe adaies none poore reason good possession destributed among multitude distributed necessarilie person exceede rated number bee extraordinarie must haue nothing whether fewe number wee see many place cause cittizens become poore pouertie engendreth sedition wickednesse phidon corinthian one ancient lawgiuers memorie man minde number house cittizens ought alwaies equall albeit first vnequall proportion lot fallen vnto contrarie bee found lawes matter wee entreate hereafter declare wee thinke fittest bee ordained furthermore hee hath omitted shewe howe magistrate authoritie differ priuate men hee sayth onely warpe made another kind thread wo • e ought magistrate differ subiects againe whereas hee permitteth encrease multiplication possession vnto fiue folde wherefore dooth hee allowe land territory vnto certaine limitation also deuision house hee maketh commodious fit houshold affaire hee assigneth euery man two distinct seuerall house hard matter one man inhabite two house besides whole discription commonwealth seemeth neither bee popular power call democratie power fewe called oligarchie forme gouernement betwixt call policie consisting men beare armour therefore hee hath propounded forme commonwealth vsuall city may bee hee hath sayed well best next vnto first hee way lacedemonian forme best men aristocratically beare rule commended opinion good commonweale ought bee compounded • ormes gouernement together respect commend lacedemonians consisteth oligarchie monarchie democratie dominion people kingly state monarchie senate oligarchie ephorie democratie magistrate tribune people called ephori taken people others thinke ephorian office plaine tyrannie democratie consisteth rather common assembly ioint banquettings ordinarie manner life law socrates declared good commonwealth must compounded two formes democratie tyrannie either formes gouernment bee yet worst therefore mingle formes together rather bee followed commonwealth compact formes gouernement best yet man would consider socrates commonwealth aduisedly hee shall finde little nothing therein belongs monarchie oligarchie democratie although encline naturally oligarchie may appeare creation magistrate create elect lot common bee necessarie rich bee assistant present publike consultation creation magistrate execution ciuill office whereas rest exempted therefrom proper oligarchie also procure greatest part beare rule commonwealth bee richer sort greatest office bee put haue greatest rich also election senate oligarchicall chuse necessarily first choice first ranke men greatest reuenue many second third except third fourth ranke necessarily chuse fourth first second ranke reuenue four constrained chuse saith must cull ranke many may equall number greatest reuenue must exceede number goodnesse asmuch populacie chuse compelled chuse therefore commonwealth cannot consist democratie monarchie cleare hath beene spoken cleare shall speake hereafter occasion shall offered also ariseth danger maner creation magistrate chusing chosen certaine conspire together though yet would election compassed vndermining according owne desire forme commonwealth plato lawes hath described plato ten bookes commonweale matter wrote twelue law twelue hath made foure first forme proeme enter principall matter beginneth treat fift wherein hee first setteth downe lawes pertaine state generall charge magigrates commeth order lawes concerne particular action cittizens whereof hee hath described forme commonweale doth differ calleth one first wherein haue thing common second lesse common aristotle continueth dispute former alleadging small difference betweene sauing community afore specified socrates first commonweale hath sleightly touched fewe matter summe breefe another iudge might easily doe first speaker accounted wisest iudgements concerning life death vse three pot one condemnation partie accused another absolution punishment forfeit third yet appeareth husbandman hauing weapon cr • f • smen hauing neither land weapon shall bee manner bound thrall souldiours therefore possible sort honour bee communicated vnto chief • tai • e head warres keeper defender citizen welneere principall magistrate must chosen men warre also husbandman craftsman haue part commonweale beare good vnto yet must souldiours need mightier greater strength part • easie matter done except bee great number purpose communicate commonweale others haue power create magistrate againe thing husbandman behoofefull citie craftsman necessary therein euery citie hath neede may get liuings occupation doe city husbandman furnish victual men warre good reason bee reckoned part city commonweale haue priuate part till ground priuately againe publicke part allotted sustenance souldiours tilled themselues souldiours nothing differ husbandman lawmaker pretendeth person employed behalfe differing husbandman souldiours make fourth part citie shall haue interest thing whatsoeuer forainers commonweale notwithstanding whosoeuer shal driue tiller priuate part manure till publicke part shall multitude haue croppe fruit serue euery furnish make pr ••• sion two house wherefore shall straightway selfesame land allotted territory take food sustenance themselues furnish souldiours thereof thing free great many disorder trouble neither law allowable concerneth iudgements appointeth vpon simple prosecution cause iudge shall diuide sentence iudge become arbitrator although course might obserued arbitrement diuerse may conferre amongst themselues iudgement giuen yet allowed court tribunall seates rather sundry lawmaker doe expressely forbid iudges manner communication betweene themselues giuing sentence againe shall bee troublesome confused manner iudging iudge thinketh somewhat due plaintife yet much plaintife affirmeth owing vnto demandeth twenty pound yet doth iudge pronounce ten pound onely due vnto iudge iudge lesse another fiue pound another four thus deuiding sentence iudges giue sentence wholly plaintife others manner shall voice opinion bee discerned reckoned againe man doth constraine iudge forsweare himselfe shall plainely condemne absolue sute simply orderly commenced prosecuted law absolueth defendant doth iudge oweth nothing twenty pound due iudge periured thinketh twenty pound due yet condemneth defendant pay aristotle hauing first recited principall article contained hippodamus milesian commonweale doth confute diuerse deuiding cittizens partition land forme iudging shewing wel ordained inconueniences might happen thereby rewarding honouring inuent thing benefite commonweale carrieth faire shew word yet dangerous put execution causeth quarrel ministreth occasion sturre alteration state question doubt whether good euill city change old ancient lawes better deuised therefore easie consent straight way decree touching honouring inuenters thing publicke profite bee expedient change lawes may fall men persuade either repealing abrogation lawes alteration forme gouernement commonweale common good forasmuch way fallen matter shall amisse stay little containeth doubt wee haue alleadged sooth yet superfluitie delicious pleasure citizen end exterminat roote side greedie desire hauing enriching hee made another third ordinance newe excellent concerning bankets willed ordained eat together company al meat none namely specified decree also expresly forbidden eat apart priuatly vpon rich table sumptuous bed abusing thus labour excellent workemen daintie cooke fat feede themselues secret darke men vse fatte rauenous greedie beast thing spoileth corrupteth onely condition mind also complexion body bridle libertie thus let loose sensualitie luxurious gluttonie whereupon followeth much phido place mutuall amity friendship engendred would haue called philitia place feast loue putting l might also bee first letter oueradded superfluous bee editia men assembled together place eate take repast thus assembled togither fifteenes thereabouts euery hall euery one brought beginning moneth bushell meale eight gallon wine fiue pound cheese two pound halfe figges ouer aboue little peece money buy meat besides sacrificed house hee sent first fruit sacrifice publicke hall likewise taken venison hunting hee sent one peece thereof thither two case onely lawfull eate priuately wit sacrificed beastes god returned late home hunting otherwise constrained bee continually present hals common meeting would eate custome obserued long strictly child also frequented meateassemblies lesse schooles honour temperance heard manie good graue sentence deuises touching gouernement commonwealth vnder maisters mercenary learnt also play vpon one another speech quippe mocke pleasantly yet without sharpe girding dishonest iesting thus mocked bee angrie discontented ordinary custome entered common hall eldest among pointing dore saied let speech spoken go dores ouer threshold also whosoeuer would receiued meatassemblies must first approued allowed residue exquisite daintie meate called blacke broth serued olde men would eate flesh left younger themselues fed vpon broth onely thus soberly eat drunke togither returned without light euery one home permitted walke either thither elsewhere candle end might accustome themselues march boldly euery night darke wel light order forme phiditia meate assembly loue feast may fitly tearme concerning light matter touching contract bargaines betwixt man man thinges often change alter sometimes sometimes fashion necessity requireth thought best tie reduce vnder written edict constraint yet establish setled custome bee changed rather leaue discretion arbitrement men ben well instructed brought vp end take adde vnto according occurrence occasion time required supposing breefe cheefe scope drift good establisher reformer commonweale ought bee cause men might bee wel instructed brought vp vertue lycurgus hath said called ordinance retres much say graue sentence oracle giuen god apollo neither would euer suffer put writing expressely mentioned one place meaning decree committed writing touching principall power force make city happy vertuous thought ought imprinted heart education maners men custome might remaine vnchangeable good willingnesse mind strongest bond bee knit made constrain men liue wel bent get good instruction first infancy maketh euery man serue stead law vnto himselfe plutarke esteemed one happy excellentest thing lycurgus brought cōmonweale namely great leisure idlenes bestowed vpon citizen suffered thē employ themselues base mechanical trade needful trauel toile heaping vp rich place wealth opulency neither profitable esteemed amongst thē nothing dauncing feast sport banquet pastime hunting exercise body like busied war solon side ordained great punishment idlenesse would euery one giue account life exercise day lawe mahomet euery one bound skilfull trade euen highest bassa child learne art lowest basest drudge time returne aristotle exposition text hauing forealleadged discourse end haue better vnderstanding thereof novv fully resolued concluded amongst • well gouerned state • principal cheefe ruler ought giue themselues necessary work plato aristotle opinion cheefe men countrey ought exercise vile base trade craft hand mercenary hireling lycurgus also ordained sparta lacedemonia matter plutarch life solon writeth thus lycurgus saith hee inhabited cittie wherein resort ariuall anie stranger large territory might sufficiently furnish twise many people resident besides enuironned side great multitude ilotians much expedient keep idlenesse alwaies hold low subiection constraining continually trauel labor themselues others wise decree wherby keepe cittizens alwaies occupied exercise armes without learning practise trade life discharging paineful occupation handicraft ilotians conspired lacedemonians ilotians men enthralled law armes tilled ground lacedemonians yeelded vnto thereout certain rent reuenue euery yeare reason often rebelled lord plutarch reporteth lacedemonia certaine secret decree gouernors ouersight youth certain periodes time select iudged best aduised send country carrying dag necessarie liuing sustenance yoong men dispersed vp downe countrey hid themselues day time couert secret place rested refreshed themselues night beset lay wait high way slew euerie ilote could find sometimes also broad day ranged field killing slaying mightiest strongest could come thucidides history peloponesian warre recordeth saith certaine ilotes good number certaine time publicke decree spartanes crowned enfranchised made free led temple god reward good seruices exploited valiantly commonwealth thus short time could perceiued become although number amounted two thousand sort neuer man heard spoken neither maner died made away aristotle besides al others affirme saieth ephories tribune soone installed office denounced warre ilotes purpose might bee lawfull kill howsoeuer well certaine amongst thinges handled roughly sometimes compelled drinke wine vnmixt water quantitie till starke drunke therewith led thus drunke common hals meat assembly shewe vnto child villanie ouglie thing bee drunke caused daunce filthie daunces vnbeseeming honest person ful derision mockery forbid • ing expressely comely honest plutarke thinketh lacedemonians begun vse notable cruelty roughnesse long death lycurgus namely great earthquake happened sparta time ilotes rebelling took part messenians committed many outrage countrey put cittie greatest danger euer plato de legibus lib 6 speaking bondslaues mentioneth ilotes penests periaeces cretan moreover libertie giuen vnto woman hurtfull incommodious purpose commonweale also happie estate thereof euen man woman part member familie likewise citie may deuided two equal part one consisting men woman citie ordering discipline woman good one halfe moyetie citie thought order lawgiuer desiring make citie temperate able sustaine labour hath attained purpose regard men woman permitted liue licentiousnesse dissolute intemperancie sort necessarily rich honoured esteemed commonwealth especially men subiection woman part amongst warlike military natione except celt openly approue vnnaturall fellowship owne sexe therefore seemeth first deuised fable without cause couple mar venus togither kind people giuen either sodomie nature hunting harlot strumpet mischiefe amongst lacedemonians part affaire ordered direction woman difference whether woman command owne person commander commanded woman doth come one passe whereas audacitie boldnesse nothing auaileable ordinary business except matter warre woman lacedemonia respect hurtfull commonweale euidently made proofe inuasion thebanes farre profitable woman city rather raised vp trouble tumult citie enemy themselues seemeth libertie permitted lacedemonian woman without iust cause men often abroad home reason continual subiection lawes hee saw made head withstand hee surceassed enterprise cause threw inconueniences consequently errour purpose inquire deserueth excuse wel ill ordained discipline woman well ordered seemeth hath beene said onely cause vndecencie indecorum commonweale also engender auarice couetousnesse lacedemonians haue euer affied ascribed much vnto woman suffering looke meddle affaire commonweale themselues affaire house plutarch life agis • nd cleomene greatest part rich vnder hand custodie woman therefore gaue much honour withall much power authoritie citie ordering discipline woman good aristotle first booke rhethoricke affirmeth citties estate affaire woman well ordered gouerned among lacedemonians one halfe felicitie happinesse seemeth wanting lawgiuer desiring make citie temperate able sustaine labour hath attained purpose regard men woman education nurture men hath beene spoken woman followeth first lawgiuer willed commanded yong woman harden inure body labour exercising running wrastling throwing barre whirling dart end fruit wombes conceiue taking deepe root lustie strong body might burnish grow better also themselues enabled made strong exercise might courage ease endure trauailes childbed might depriue delicacie effeminate tendernesse hee accustomed young maid well young men labour dance naked certaine feast solemne sacrifice sing presence yong gallant whome oftentimes would giue bitter cut touching quicke forgotten duty respect sometimes also rehearsed song praise commendation deserued whereby engraued heart yong men exceeding great emulation contention honour hee commended valour prowesse presently lifted vp courage attempt greater matter afterward bitings quippes gaue vnto others lesse stinging sharpe seuere admonition chastisement could come vnto considering done presence king senator whole people came alwaies together see hear contention touching maid shewed themselues naked publicke plutarch striueth excuse saying thereupon arose amongst naughtinesse vncleannesse strife contention accompanied al honestie modesty void immodestie lecherie yea rather contrary carried accustoming inuring discipline countrey emulation amongst themselues haue strongest lustiest bodie lifted vp sort heart courage made valiant magnanimious making knowne lesse seemely exercise professe prowesse contend among themselues haue prize men whence proceeded lacedemonian woman heart speake thinke themselues gorgon wife king leonidas one day answered strange lady deuising saying woman world saue lacedemonian ouerruled commanded men replied woman world bring forth men saue moreouer bait allure yong men marry mean sport daunces contention yong maid practised presence young men yet besides allurement appointed note infamie discredite refused marrie would marry also must first rauish force maid would espouse haire shauen vnto bare skin attired men garment breech placed bed alone vpon certaine pallet new married came lie candia amongst lacedemonians euery man bound bring portion feast notwithstanding bee poore able furnish charge insomuch contrary lawgiuer entended resulteth happeneth vnto would haue institution feast democraticall howbeit ordained wise democraticall easie poore folke bee also ancient law admitteth man commonweale able beare contribution manner assembling meat hath beene already declared euery man furnished certain quantitie victual assembly consisting fifteenes whosoeuer could furnish rate excluded honour office commonweale course aristotle blameth affirming better haue made feast charge commonweale men also haue iustly blamed law touching admiral law cause sedition adding king head warres perpetuall authoritie power sea manner ordeining another kingdome forasmvch haue sought commonweale abase kingly state moderate diuerse meanes forgot themselues added vnto perpetuall authority sea manner double authority power sea land yet lawmaker inuention may blamed also plato hath found fault lawes institution lawes tendeth one vertue namely warlike fortitude serueth victory therefore preserued themselues warring conquered gotten themselues empire presently vndone could liue rest doe better exercise exercise warre neither errour lesse thinke good fight ought rather bee gotten vertue vice fer though bee well said yet erre esteeming worthier vertue plato first booke de legibus aristotle seuenth booke politicks chap 2 3 14 polybye history lib 6 doe blame commonweale lycurgus warlike saying lawes well ordained make men valiant make iust vpright notwithstanding plutarke answering sayth lycurgus shot marke leaue city commanding ouer many rather deeming felicity well cittie particular man dooth cheefly consist exercise vertue vnity concord inhabitant hath composed framed forme gouernement end cittizens waxe free hearted content owne temperate deed long maintenance conseruation state selfesame intention also plato diogenes zenon haue writing book wherein haue reasoned gouernment commonweales likewise great skilfull personage haue vndertaken write matter haue left nothing behind writing bare word xenophon matched learning chiualrie great captaine time treatise lacedemonian commonweale dooth wonderfullly commend institution lycurgus hee martiall man returning famous expedition asia withdrew himselfe iurisdiction lacedemonians hee liued great banished cittie athens whereof hee naturall subiect therefore preserued themselues warring conquered gotten themselues empire thē presently vndone could liue rest aristotle polit lib 7 cap 14 writeth thus lawgiuer ought rather bend wit referre affaire warre lawes rest peace euents agreeing reason doe sufficiently witnesse sith diuerse citties making warres haue beene preserued haue conquered gotten empire doe perish decay rust time peace like yron whereof lawgiuer cause hath taught liue peace well war sith therefore day lacedemonians haue dominion certaine happy lawmaker good mockery persisting still lawes hauing hinderance vse thereof haue lost notwithstanding happie life time lacedemonians began take ease diminished also little little destroyed noble famous commonweale like whereof vpon selfesame occasion afterwards befe •• romanes also cheefe senatours foresaw would come passe amongst whome scipio nasica onescipio nasica opinion carthage albeit enuious renowme name rome perpetuall enemie thereto bee rased destroied end might alwaies haue enemie whome fight shew themselues arm enemy enuious person wholly ouerthrowne destroyed danger commonweale rome instructed furnished warres romane youth brought vp martiall affaire would turne weapon themselues worke owne decay counsell although refused senate yet disposition matter fell shewed well wise discreet counsell • ither errour lesse lacedemonians erre also esteeme vertue victory sake wherevnto referre doings last cheefe end saying concerning matter except victorie getting whereof paine ought bee taken sought appertaine lacedemonians doe exact subsidy one another care diligence meanes whereof lawgiuer hath attained commoditie pretended cleane contrary hath made cittie p • ore particular person couetous gaue authoritie iudge matter except say letter law darke must holpen somewhat supplied therein wanteth giuing interpretation followeth vnto wit shall bee attainted conuict matter whereof court cittie number solon himselfe hee perceiued people fierce bold reason felt themselues discharged debt erected another second counsell matter state chusing hundred men euery tribe foure charge consult debate matter deliuered people end vpon assemblie great counsel matter put forth first well debated considered counsell foure hundred ordained soueraine court haue eye ouersight thinges specially concerning maintenance obseruation keeping lawes • eeming commonweale stayed two court two strong ancres bee lesse beaten vpon lesse tormented common people would thereby bee peaceable quiet ephialtes afterwards serued turne court areopage body whereof neuer member lot fallen time vnto bee neither yeerely prouost guardant lawes king sacrifice maister warres officer olde time created lot • lot fell determination many matter taken helpe entermedling ephialtes procured banishment cymon fauouring lacedemonians contrarying welfare authoritie people although hee one richest noblest men cittie gotten alone together gouerne cōmonweale question propounded whether vertue good cittizen good man one answered cannot first many formes cōmonweales necessary fit vertue citizen kind commonweale wherein liueth cannot one vertue citizen cōmonweales secondly city cannot consist good mē yet good citizen must indued ciuil vertue seemeth respect vertue good man good citizen cannot seeing city consisteth vnlike person euen vertues thus vnlike must need diuers followeth vertue cannot al alike notwithstā ding good cōmonweale vertue thē one albeit double vertue required also one teach men obey wel cōmand wel latter greater perfect thē former obey well required fortitude temperance euen necessary cōmand wel yet differing frō kind nature though name • neuerthelesse good citizen good man ought haue although ech thē called properly good vertue perfect amongst vertues wisdome fit cōmander necessary obeyer question thus decided returneth consider citizen declareth many sort kind therof affirmeth well gouerned city mechanicall artsmen mercenary person vnfit exercise workes vertue ought bee placed receiued ranke order true citizen bee esteemed free honestly brought vp capable office publicke honour contarin de repub • et lib 1 salust second oration iulius caesar touching ruling reformation romane commonwealth haec igitur multitudo primum mali moribus c therefore rude multitude first infected corrupt manner condition dispersed diuers art trade life respect agreeable vnitie together doth seeme vnto thing fit rule commonwealth herod lib 2 affirmeth thracian scythian persian lydian almost barbarous nation doe hold artificer vilest basest sort people world yea also child whole race doe repute noble generous farthest mechanicall art especially make profession arm graecians mind aboue lacedemonians also corinthian make small account artificer fraunce gentleman account estimation ancient ordinance countrie forbidden commerce merchandise euery gainfull art vnder paine depriued gentilitie paying taxe custome like common clowne carter plato also 2 8 book de repub • beginning timeus writeth gentleman soldiors abstaine husbandrie mechanicall trade gainfull occupation old time landes reuenues designed set aegypt maintainance soldiours end might wholy addict themselues exercise arm without practising base art trade alarbians greatly detest mechanicall art againe thus among themselues fift kind administration one sole lord euery nation euery citie hath power ouer common thing followeth example oeconomie oeconomie kinde houshold gouernment gouernement citie oeconomie one nation nowe almost two kindes gouernement whereof wee speake laconicall others greater part mean betwixt two either king haue lesse authoritie absolute commonweale laconicall wherefore whole matter consisteth two point one whether bee profitable citie haue continual gouernour generall warres hee bee created succession stocke linage whether hee bee elected suffrage according vertue dignitie person whether bee profitable whether bee profitable haue kingdome gouerned one solely although consideration captaine pertaineth rather lawes commonweale thing cannot happen euery commonweale leauing therefore first manner gouernement let v come forme commonweale let v breefely resolue doubt therein beginning question whether bee expedient commonweale bee administred good man good lawes thinke expedient city bee gouerned king doe suppose lawes doe speake onely generall tearmes prouide particular case therefore would absurd foolish commaund anie art according prescript rule lawes aegypt phisitions permitted meddle disease fourth day past doe minister time perill hazard wherefore apparent best forme regiment followeth letter lawe yet necessarie vniuersall reason bee gouernours must needes bee better voide passion perturbation minde naturally affected therewith nowe lawe without passion minde man necessarily subiect vnto perturbation peraduenture may obiect good man recompence hauing affection able iudge particular case lawe cannot doe therefore necessarie hee bee lawedisposer also bee lawes written yet fullie confirmed vnuiolable regard maie differ varie truth namely thinges within compasse lawes albeit thinges must bee ratified question whether one good man solely manie togither ought gouerne nowe adaies manie assembled togither doe discusse consult iudge matter iudgements particular case therefore one whatsoeuer hee bee compared manie farre inferiour cittie consisteth manie euen banquet prepared furnished manie exquisite simple table therefore multitude iudgeth better anie one able doe multitude lesse subiect corruption one like water plentifull lesse putrifieth one iudge ouercome choller anie passion must iudgement needes bee depraued whereas multitude cannot bee chollericke deceaued let v suppose multitude doe nothing contrarie lawe needes must bee hard bee found amongst manie yet least manie good men good cittizens question esteeme excellent thing beare rule ouer forasmuch meanes man may able performe many honest iust exploit able gouerne ought lay burthen gouernement vpon anothers shoulder rather take another without bee found excelling rest vertue ability performe good deed honest thing yeeld vnto iust thing obey ought haue onely vertue work also power wherewith worke therefore person much excell others amongst according report herodotus first booke thought good transcribe place fit present matter touching king kingdome medes sayeth inhabiting townes village amongst found one deioces man highly reputed territorie applying heart iustice executed carefully albeit throughout countrey medea bridle let loose licentiousnesse libertie yet hee well knowing iustice enemie vnto vice behaued himselfe notwithstanding inhabitant town vnderstanding chose iudge estate one longed dominion hee demeaned himselfe iustly vprightly gained himselfe great reputation townes began vnderstand howe deioces onely man countrey gaue iudgement according right equitie wherefore flocked vnto haue iustice side vniust sentence wrong sustained last came passe came none yea euery day great multitude flocked regard vpright dealing hee perceiued countrey relied vpon hee would longer keepe court accustomed place exercise office iudge alleadging imploying himselfe distribute iustice vnto others • hee neglected owne affaire endammaged himselfe againe robbery ryots insolencies rebudded amongst medes preuent mischeefes assembled togither disputed prouision office time mine opinion friendes deioces spake brauely maisters saied wee alwayes liue kinde life wee nowe lead impossible v remaine longer countrey wherefore wee aduise establish king amongst v onely meanes prouide countrey may bee iustly vprightly gouerned returne v backe discharge charge come passe wee shall bee destroyed ruined peruerse condition speech stirred vp persuasion king needefull dore opened presently euery one bethought deioces extolled greatly vntill one consent hee chosen established king done hee commaunded helpe build house fit king designe guard safetie medes presently layed industruous hand erected great strong castle place hee marked suffered chuse whome hee would bee guard hee perceiuing himselfe thus confirmed king constrained medes moreouer build cittie furnish royally thinges necessary obey builded direction high strong wals enclosed within day called ecbatanes description building manner one wals higher except prospect turret scituation place helpeth much found vpon little hill sheweth industrie seuen inclosure wals enuironned one within another within last least king pallace treasure preserued widest large whole citie athens turret first enclosure enamelled white second blacke third carnation fourth azure fift orange tawney sixt seuenth one siluer golde deioces thinges thus performed commanded people lodge round citie afterwards hee first ordained none date present himselfe king huishers messenger also none bee bold looke king face bee accounted base dishonest part either laugh spit king medes doe willingly obserue lawes end age king haue beene brought vp men worth looking vpon bee vnprofitable pleasure glavc doubtlesse socr kind person doth liue afterwards seemeth much necessary vnnecessary pleasure employing thereon good labour exercise hee bee happy abandon himselfe much growing yeares pleasure doe great number present themselues vnto take part therof mean leaue rest though wholly addict himselfe hath taken yet liue sort hee doth equally vse euer submitting himselfe first shall subdue vntill bee therewith glutted take another setting light cherishing alike glavc may happen socr doth admit receiue true reason fort •• sse doth shew pleasure honest good desire bad desire hee must exercise honour one moderate bridle hee agreeth point affirming pleasure alike equally bee honoured glavc man thus addicted doth socr thus liues hee secure gratifying embracing first wherein neuerthelesse erre democratie citizen sort equall doe thinke themselues absolutely equall haue like libertie thinke themselues altogether like oligarchie vnequall thing vnequall thing vnequall bee proportionally obserued euery commonweale yet equall one thing poore men democraties equally free absolutely equall thing others vnequall one thing bee vnequall thing rich men nobleman oligarchie feeke absolutely preferred exceed rich nobility although bee inferiour vertue wherefore sort citizen hauing part gouernment thinke doth right belong vn • raise sedition whereby estate chaunged one sedition namely gouernors people democraties oligarchie people people least whereof reckoning made moreouer commonweale consisteth meane men surest safest commonweales doth approch neerer democratie oligarchie ordaine commonweale simply respect according one equality good arithmeticall equality selfe bad geometricall alone cannot altogether obserued without mutiny must mixed preuenting men discontent socrates areopagiticall oration saith much helpe profite gouernment city whereas two sort equality one giueth alike meet ignorant whether two profitable left equality giueth alike good bad obserued aforesaid gouernement equality distributeth honour punishment according desert chusing magistrate indifferently people better sort doth wholly mislike arithmeticall equality sought democraticall person commendeth geometricall notwithstanding must bee obserued alone euen commonweales thereby ordered viz oligarchy aristocraties rich selfe nobility giue absolute right authority gouerne sort none may beare rule saue rich noble neither vertue alone doe good vertuous man many estate noble rich likewise well ordered commonweale office giuen good men principall wherein consisteth authoritie state administred sole person small number end rest honoured excluded gouernement commonweale grow discontented vse practises tending innouation sith commonweale continuance democratie doth simply point obserue right mentioned according arithmetical equality continuance reason sedition spring therein oligarchie hath respect geometricall equality reason impossible errour committed first bad beginning proceed bad end beginning force thing thing well begun accounted halfe done thing ill begunne haue sildome good euent wherefore meruell two formes commonweales prosper soone decay sith beginning grounded true equall right outward apparence wherefore behoueth vse partly equality number partly equality according dignity well establishing commonweale preseruing sedition requisite mixe temper two equality together plato sixt lawes necessary euery citty would altogether exempted sedition vse two equality hauing like denomination commendable equity equall discerning perfect absolute violated done right iudgement wherefore expedient vse equality lot thereby auoid giuing offence many behalf god good fortune bee praied vnto lot may bee directed fall best iustest sort equality must bee vsed necessity sort lesse hath need fortune cause therefore order must bee thus obserued cittie desireth continuance safety another place booke amongst magistrate chosen proportion wealth reueuues one halfe bee created lot bee senatours yeare kind creation bee middle forme betweene monarchicall democraticall two formes commonweale ought alwaies keepe meane otherwise lord slaues neuer agree good bad cittizens doe equally participate publicke honor amongst men vnequall equall thing doe become vnequall receaue prescribed measure doth therefore hereby appeare experience mistresse teacher thing doth sufficiently shewe two sort equalitie must mixed well ordered commonweale wee see humane society priuate publicke consisteth due communication commutation thing order degree person communication thing made contract bargaines wherein great equalitie must bee obserued arithmeticall proportion doth simply retaine equall difference among many number cause penaltie like like called p • ena talionis auncient time ordained restoring equalitie touching person office ordered appointed degree citties priuate family city cheefe meane inferiour magistracy family diuerse degree parent child brother sister lord slaues order person must bee established geometricall proportion retaining equalitie proportion wit giuing euery man place vsing according quality desert yet democratie surer lesse subiect mutiny oligarchie although bee corrupt yet lesse euill danger democratie oligarchie lesse troubled sedition approcheth neerer meane oligarchy arise two kind sedition namely betweene gouernors people oligarchicall person richest noblest doe agree well together oft time destroy expulse afford part authority gouernement poorer sort many number doe besides oppresse necessary become enemy vnto 3 book politickes chap 7 conspire shall afterward bee shewed plato eight commonweale fourth lawes gouernour bvt democraties oligarchie people people least whereof reckoning made democratie sedition raised poor rich poor doe neuer seldome cōtend amongst themselues nothing thereby bee gotten doe time small sedition consequence moreover commonweale consisteth mean men say hauing meane substance neither rich poore surest commonweales fourth booke politickes chap 11 wit corrupt commonweales haue already swarued perfection commonweale doth approch neerer democratie oligarchie meane forme commonweale hath affinity democratie oligarchie cause democratie surer safer lesse corrupt likewise 8 ethickes chap 10 saieth democratie bad doth little transgresse exceed right forme commonweale 4 politicks chap 11 hee saith democraties surer longer continuance reason meane estate greater number haue interest publicke honour commonly city three sort people rich oligarchy poore democraties third sort meane betweene neither poore rich manie haue authoritie gouernment without doubt state cittie assured lesse troubled sedition cittizens rich poore fit maintaining humane society rich prowd disdainefull prone offer iniuries poore malicious enuious cannot long remaine together without tumult faction stronger falling quarrel hauing aduantage enemy doe alwaies cause state commonweale encline side bee poore establish democratie rich oligarchie part men meane estate reason see democraties oligarchy formes commonweales meane sort cittizens doe neither desire men good poore doe neither insolent rich meanes mainetaine publicke amitie eschewe sedition wherefore commonweale gouerned men meane substance best longest continuance neither happen greater good estate safetie haue gouernours meanly rich otherwise fall presently monarchicall popular tyranny worse vtterly destroied chap ii vvhence sedition spring cause sith come consider whence sedition chaunges commonweales doe spring first touch generall beginning cause thereof three number wee breefly discourse seuerally selfe first must know howe men disposed made prone sedition next wherefore raise thirdly wh • beginning ciuile trouble mutiny tumult arise amongst cause disposed desire change generall whereof haue lately spoken viz seeking equality doe mutine thinke haue lesse themselues equall haue others seeking inequalitie preheminence doe likewise mutine vnequall persuade themselues haue alike lesse nowe thing may sometimes bee iustly desired sometimes vniustly reason inferiour contend equality equall superioritie hereby appeareth disposed sedition desire innouation thinges contend profite honour contrary seeking shunne dishonour daunger either themselues friendes trouble city estate sedition cause beginning motiues dispose aforesaid manner thinges v mentioned may bee seuen number somewhat two whereof former manner profite honour doe prouoke quarrell contend together thereby purchase themselues said see others aduanced iustly vniustly likewise prouoked reason iniuries feare prepotence contempt excessiue encrease otherwise shame negligence pusillanimity vnlikenesse euery sedition three point considered first men disposed made prone raising second end mutine third motiue cause thereof equality inequality democraties oligarchy doe dispose incline men discord end finall cause thereof profite manlius romane hystories may find certaine slaues haue ben authours sedition herdonius sabinus raised warre called bellum seruile one named eunus syrian gathered power forty thousand slaues sicile hauing put kingly attire ranged island wasting spoiling also another borne cilicia much mischeefe spartacus swordplayer rising state rome fought many time romane consul discomfited battaile afterward vanquished l crassus materiall cause sedition whome raised whome superiours prince magistrate inferiours subiect vnto end finall cause sedition thing raised aristotle setteth downe foure end thereof namely profite honour contrary dammage dishonour men commonly stirred thereunto hope profite honour feare dammage infamy well themselues friend desiring one shunning profite referre rich honour magistracy office publicke charge dammage pouertie dishonour continuall iniuries contempt like although numbred among motiue efficient cause sedition prouoke men yet may likewise bee end thereof obtaining shunning men doe conspire forme manner sedition commotion people noise cry beating murthers ciuile warre surprizing townes burning banishment bee subiects toward superiours lord called rebellion betweene subiects men equall estate faction titus liuius second booke first decade doth elegantly describe forme sedition happened rome debt manner magno natu quidam cum omnium maiorum suorum insignibus se forum proiecit obsita erat squalore vestis foedior corporus habitus pallore ac macie perempti adhoc promissa barba capilli esfer •• erant speciem oris noscitabatur tamen tanta deformitate ordines duxisse aiebant aliáque mititiae decora vulgo miserantes eum iactabant ipse testis honestarum aliquot locis pugn • rum cicatrix aduersopectore • stentabat sciscitantibus vnde esset ille habitus vnde deformitas quum circunsusa turba esset propè concionis modum sabino bello ait se militantem quta propter populationes agri non fructu modò car • erit sed villa incensa fuerit dirrepta omnia pecora abacta tributum iniquo suo tempore imperatum aes alienum secisse id cum • latum vsuris primò se agro paterno auitòque exuisse deinde fortunis alijs postremò velut tabem peruenisse ad corpus ductum se ab creditore non seruitium sed ergastulum carnificinam esse inde ostentare tergum foedum recentibus f • igijs verberum ad haec visa auditàque clamor ingens oritur non iam foro se tumultus continet sed passim totam vrbem peruadit nexu vincti solutíque se vndique publicum proripiunt implorant quiritium fidem nullo loco deest seditionis volontarius come multis passim agminibus per omnes viat cum clamore forum curritur magno cum periculo suo qui fortè patrum foro erant eam turbam inciderunt nec temperatum manibus foret ni properè cos p seruilius appius claudius ad comprimendam seditionem interuenissent eos multitudo versa ostentare vincula sua deformitatémque aliam haec se meritos dicere exprobrantes suam quisque alius alibi militiam postulare minaciter magi quàm suppliciter vt senatum vocarent curi • mque ipsi futuri arbitri moderatorésque publici consilij circumsistunt also another description much vnlike made authour third booke decade sedition raised manner outrage committed appius daughter virginius repraesentatur mactaturus iam pater filiam abrepto ab lanio cultro hoc te vno quo possum ait modofilia inlibertatem vendico pectus deinde puellae transfigit respectánsque ad tribunal te inquit appi tuúmque caput sanguine hoc consecro clamore ad tam atrox facinus orto excitus appius comprehendi virginium iubet ille ferro quacunque ibat viam facere donec multitudine etiam prosequentium iuuenum ruente ad portam perrexit icilius numitoriúsque exangue corpus sublatum ostentant populo scelus appij puellae infelicem fortunam necessitatem patris deplorant sequentes clamitant matronae eám ne procreandorum liberorum conditionem ea pudicitiae praemia esse concitatur multitudo clamatur ad arma cicero oration pro ta milone compareth people incensed tempest et quidem inquit caeteras tempestates procellas illis duntaxat fluctibus concionum seditionum authour first booke de oratore hoc tempus post consulatum obiecimus fluctibus qui per no à communi pest • depulsi nosmetipsos redundarunt dooth virgil likewise first booke aeneide ac veluti magno populo cum sepe coorta est seditio saeuítque animis ignobile vulgus iámque face • saxa volant furor arma ministrat tum pietate grauem meritis si fort • virum quem conspexere silent arrectisque auribus astant ille regit dictis animos pectora mulcet sic cunctus pelagi cecidit fragor aequora postquam prospiciens genitor coelóque inuectus aperto flectit equos currúque volans dat lora secundo vnlikenesse plato eight commonweale sayeth wheresoeuer vnlikenesse discordant inequalitie men disposed made prone sedition abundance wealth much ease sallustius bello iugurthin • caeterum mo partium popularium senatus factionum ac deinde omnium malarum artium paucis antè annis romae ortus est otio atque abundantia earum rerum quae prima mortales ducunt likewise extreame pouertie doth much incite men euill horace foure twentith ode third booke magnum pauperies opprobrium iubet quid vi facere pati virtutis que viam deserit arduae plato fift booke lawes sayeth thus must bee neither extreme pouertie excessiue rich among citizen cittie would exempted greeuous disease called dissention sedition salust conspiracie catiline speaketh thus poore men nam semper ciuitate quibus opes nullae sunt bonis inuident male extollunt vetera odere noua exoptant odio suarum rerum mutari omnia student turba atque seditionibus sine cura aluntur quoniam egestas facile sine damno habetur manie country haue beene much troubled sedition could indure excessiue multitude inhabitant thereon haue growne many transmigration remouings people one region another likewise estate enclined sedition hath enemie hanniball told carthaginian speaking thus tenth booke third decade liuie nulla magna ciuitas quiescere potest si foris hostem non habet domi inuenit vt praeualida corpus ab externis causis tuta videntur sed suis ipsa viribus onerantur great citty remaine quiet haue enemie abroad findeth one home euen great body seeme bee safe assured outward danger yet surcharged ouerladen owne force cause scipio nasica opinion victorie romanes carthaginian carthage bee raced least romanes hauing enemy gouerne doe easily attempt suppresse put downe change commonweales doe happen also reason excessiue increase body consisteth part must grow proportion end due measure may still remaine whereas otherwise perishe • h foot foure • ubit • long rest body two spannes might likewise bee chaunged shape liuing creature grow beyond doe proportion onely quantity qualitie also euen city consisteth part amongst oft time one doth priuily growe vp multitude poore men democraties commonweales sometimes also dooth happen chaunce tarentum greater part nobility vanquished destroied iapigians long warre medes state commonweale become democratie argo slaughter people • doma cleomenes lacedemon constrained receiue bordering stranger make member citie athens sought vnhappily battaile land lacedemonians nobleman decreased sent warre according catalogue city like doth happen democraties also seldome • many men growing rich wealth encreased chaunged oligarchy potentacies euery commonweale composed degree estate part estate must bee kept held concord due proportion euen harmony musicke consisteth vnequall voice sound equally accorded estate doth rise much aboue doth forwith insue dissention city like discord song one tune low another high romane commonweale composed three degree order namely patrician knight plebeian estate kept within proportion thinges went well one rose enuy ambition auarice began diuisions dangerous faction ij gracchi abridge senatours authority tooke order exercise iudgements gaue knight whose power thereby encreased v • fata fortunásque patrum vitásque principum manu haberent qui interceptis vectigalibus iure suo rempublicam peculati sun • romanes italian senator themselues necessity appeare iudgement knight touching cause soeuer controuersie money honour offence knight meanes exalted aboue ma prince senatours made subiect bound assisting tribune creation officer taking whome themselues listed conspiracie made betweene put senate great feare estate also weakening impouerishing proportion stronger haue weaker little none concord depriued onely common publicke commodity also spoiled owne priuate good people rome tiberius grac • hus spake thus sauage beast italy least hole caues dennes wherein shrowd themselues men fought died defence thereof enioyed nothing saue onely aire light constrained wander vp downe wiues child hauing place house wherinto put head quoth captaines commonly lie encourage souldiours require admonish fight valiantly graues temple altar themselues auncestors among many poore romane cittizens shewe one domesticke altar graue auncestours silly wretch fight die effeminate pleasure richesse superfluity others yet falsely called lord commander habitable world whereas haue one foot ground owne plutarch life ij gracchi fraunce two principall degree order nobilitie people whereto church although participate adioined third reuerence religion reason great reuenues cleargie land house fee exceeding profites amounting yearely foure million pound whereto adde authority hath long time iudgement parliament neere king counsell doubt agreement estate hath caused realme continue prosper long amongst auncient moderne kingdomes publicke commodity honour charge ordinarily deuided according condition euery estate without abridging right preheminences especially taking diligent heed neither doe aboue measure exceede viz nobility doe much oppresse people thereby driue despaire ommitting diligent heed hath oft caused people rise wherof hath ensued great mischeefe people mean merchandise iudgements disposing publicke reuenues together gainefull priuiledges possessed ouergreatly enrich themselues preiudice nobilitie purchase nobleman land impouerished could able sustaine charge warre serue king army whereto necessary haue alwaies speciall regard saf • ty quiet french dominion commonweales likewise changed reason shame happened heraea magistrate chosen election afterwards created lot manner election obserued bestowed publick office men worth heraea citty arcadia whose gouernement popular wherein men worth chosen magistrate like themselues heraeans derided changed custome election vse lot thereby shunne like derision long since counsell fraunce excessiue number maisters request extraordinarie secretary office treasurie afterward shame caused withdraw themselues vnseemely vnmeet treat high weightie affaire kept secret multitude reason negligence suffer attaine soueraigne office friend commonweale oreum oligarchie destroyed heracleodorus become magistrate changed said oligarchie commonweale democratie herein double negligence first doe call elect admit great office vnworthy person take pleasure executing therof suffer men attaine soueraigne magistracy dislike present manner gouernment lord berne chuse auoyer venetian duke whose disposition desire contrary forme commonweale cardinal pope religion • king france create constable chauncellour affected royall monarchicall estate second negligence called dignitie office shewe themselues slacke carelesse administration exercise thereof see part bishop prelate regard dutie ecclesiasticall charge may freely follow secular affaire cause contemned disorder haue risen great scandales meruellous trouble may easily lamented remoued reformed abuse haue long time taken deepe root fvrthermore change estate grow little little say little little many time happeneth great change manner lawes without perceiued neglecting small thing ambracia aduanced office men small reuenues end admitted none nothing little neere nature whit different change vnlesse violent doe sildome happē ordinarily bred little little euen season yeare doe degree passe excessiue heat excessiue cold winter sharpenesse summer extremity wherefore farre difficult remedy preuent commonly men take heed euils danger vntill growne great aristotle sayeth 6 booke politickes chap 4 whosoeuer consider change hath happened fraunce within thirtie yeares shall find great well religion manner lawes yet hath chanced one time little little grew continuance likewise inhabitant one place natiue breedeth sedition among vntill grow generall accord city composed euery multitude also constituted euery time wherefore haue hetherto receiued stranger city dwell therein haue part beene troubled sedition achaian dwelt troezenians city sybaris afterward grown stronger draue thing caused great euill sybarite like among thurians dwelt seeking appropriate themselues greater part territory beene owne discomfited exp • lsed byzantine practise intended enterprise stranger discouered draue force armes citie antissaeans hauing receiued banished chians afterward expulse likewise plain force zanchaeans also hauing receiued samians ouercome driuen city apollonian • dwell neere sea pontus receiuing stranger troubled sedition syracusans freed tyrans made many stranger hired souldiers fellow citizen troubled likewise sedition end fell fighting amphipolites taking city chalcidians almost driuen commonly seene naturall inhabitant citty seldome agree stranger dwelling amongst difference doe oft spring sedition appeareth example aristotle alledgeth confirmation wherof may adde geneua whether many stranger repairing well frenchman others religion alwaies maligned repined naturall citizen although done great good vnto citty reason repaire thether grew rich populous whereas poore small haue beene many conspiracy made expulse kill especially perin plotted yeare 1556 begun bee effected executed caluine thrust himselfe betweene naked sword appease tumult beza reporteth life touching receiuing stranger great regard bee number whether small great fewe quarrell naturall inhabitant lesse danger exceede number power confidence owne strength soone raise sedition likewise men different manner doe hardly agree beginning haue long remained dwelt together doe kind quiet sort conuerse salust speaking troians aborigine auncient inhabitant descended strange people writeth thus hi postquam vna moenia conuenere dispari genere aissimili lingua alius alio viuentes incredibile memoratu est quam facile coal • erint first gaules frenchman diuerse nation language religion could well agree frenchman baptised together religion accustomed themselues vnto manner language gaules two people forthwith reduced one body meruellously prosper lacedemonians permitted straungers dwell amongst day china cathay accesse entrance denied merchant remaining hauens make shewe ware sell haue commodity aske brought vnto done inhabitant presently withdraw themselues without conference farther trafficke romanes herein courteous receiue stranger citie graunting right freedome thereof also aduance publicke honour office purpose excellent oration made emperour claudius senate recorded cornelius tacitus eleuenth booke history caesar nam cùm inquit tacitus de supplendo senatu ageretur ac primores galliae qui foedera ciuitatem romanam pridem assecuti • ius adipiscendorum honorum vrbe expetissent ac multus super ea revariúsque rumor studijs diuersis apud principem certaretur asseuerantium non ita aegram italiam vt senatum vrbi suae suppeditare nequiret suffecisse olim indigenas consanguineis populis nec poenitere veteris reipublicae princeps contrà disseruit vocato senatu ita exorsus est maiores mei quorum antiquissimus clausus origine sabina simul ciuitatem romanam familiam patritioram ascitus est hortantur vti paribus consilijs rempublicam capessam transferendo huc quod vsquam egregium fuerit neque enim ignoro iulios alba coruncanos camerio porcios tusculo ne vetera scrutemur etruria lucaniáque omni italia senatum accitos postremo ipsam ad alpes promotam vt non modò singuli viritim sed terrae gentésque nomen nostrū coalescerent tunc solida domi quies aduersus externa floruimus cùm transpadani ciuitatem recepti cúm specie deductarum per orbem terrae legionum additis prouincialium validissimis fesso imperio subuentum est num poenitet balbos ex hispania nec minus insignes viros è gallia narbonensi transiuisse manent posteri eorum nec amore hanc patriam nobis concedunt quid aliud exitio lacedemonijs atheniensibus fuit quanquam armis pollerent nisi quòd victos pro alienigenis arcebant conditur nostri romulus tantum sapientiae valuit vt plerosque populus eodem die hostes dein ciues habuerit aduenae no regnauerunt libertinorum filijs magistratus mandati non vt plerique falluntur recens sed priori populo factum est cum senonibus pugnauimus scilicet volsci aequi nunquam aduersam nobis aciem instruxere capti à gallis sumus sed tuscis obsides dedimus samnitum iugum subiuimus attamen si cuncta bella recenseas nullum breuiore spacio quàm aduersus gallos consectum continuum inde ac fida pax moribus artibus affinitatibus nostris mixti aurum opes suas inferant potius quàm separati habeant omnia pc quae nunc vetustissima creduntur noua fuere plebeij magistratus post patritios latini post plebeios caeterarum italiae gentium post latino inueterascet hoc quoque quod hodie exemplis tuenur inter exempla erit haec claudius princeps quam sententiam secuto senatu make shewe set saile vnseemely sight looke reason mutuall discord likewise marriners fancy haue neuer anie stay certaintie shunning vast depth maine sea dangerous tempest wont arise saile along shore like effect hath oft happened athenian cōmonweale hath sometimes valure • well people cheefe commander auoided many greeuous calamity hath neuerthelesse cōmitted maruellous ouersights extreame rashnesse end hauing wee say wind poupe fortune wil one time people seeing thēselues great distresse voluntarily surrender soueraigne authority gaue twenty cheefe chosen personage committed charge
